title: Response Paper #X
text:
This an optional template for the response papers for our class. You can work directly on the .Rmd file or use it as a guideline to work on your own file. The only restriction is that your submission to Avenue must be a PDF. See the syllabus for formatting and extension guidelines.
If you are working off the template, see https://www.rstudio.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/rmarkdown-cheatsheet.pdf for some tips on common writing operations in Rmarkdown.
Start by replacing the relevant information in the preamble of the document. Including the number of the response paper, your personal details, and the reference to the week about which you are writing the paper.
The Overview section should indicate which reading for the week you are discussing, it summarizes its main finding and relevance in 2-3 sentences, and then briefly highlights the point that you want to make in your response. For example, in this response paper I want to criticize the use of a convenience sample instead of a representative sample. The overview should not take more than 2-3 paragraphs.

title: Response Paper #X
text:
Sub-sections
It may help to organize your thoughts into subsections so that you can address them one at a time.

title: Public Opinion and Policy
text:
This course explores quantitative research designs to answer questions about public opinion and policy in academia, government, and industry. In this website you will find all the course materials. Assignments must be submitted through Avenue.

Instructor


Course details


Contact

title: Quasi-experiments II
text:
We continue the conversation on quasi-experiments. This time we focus on difference-in-differences, a research design that relies on repeated observations of units before and after a policy is implemented to make claims about cause and effect. Unlike the previous week, we are not pretending that our data looks as if an experiment was conducted.
The lab discusses difference-in-differences designs.

title: Quasi-experiments II

title: Week 12: NO CLASS DUE TO INSTRUCTOR TRAVEL
text:
I have to cancel our meeting for this week. The course content has shifted one week.
You can participate in the following optional activities to improve your grade:

Redo one of your previously submitted labs, or complete a lab that you missed
Submit a response paper for one of the weeks that you may have missed

You can do up to one lab and up to one response paper. These are due on April 2 at 11:59 PM.
I hope this helps to make a smoother end of the semester.

title: Field Experiments II
text:
This is the second week of field experiments. We discuss block randomization and pre-post designs as variants from the canonical design. The Diaz and Rossiter (2023) reading is a bit technical, focus on understanding what block randomization and pre-post designs are. I suggest paying attention to sections 1 through 3 and then skimming the rest.
The lab focuses on the trade-offs of adopting these research design variants.

title: Evidence-Informed Policy
text:
This week we change topics. We’ll start our discussion of public policy with an introduction to the evidence-informed policy movement. This movement emerges from collaborations between governments and academics using cutting-edge statistical techniques to produce more credible evidence to determine what policies work, where, and why.
The lab discusses hypothesis testing, a commonly used approach to quantify statements on whether a policy works.

title: Survey Experiments
text:
Some of the techniques we discussed last week to reduce sensitivity bias were survey experiments. A survey experiment uses random assignment to administer different pieces of information to respondents, and then compares changes in response to a common outcome. This week, we formalize the potential outcomes framework as a way to establish functional relationships in a model. This framework is useful to understand what we can learn in experiments, survey experiments included.
The lab explores the properties of some commonly used survey experimental designs.

title: Survey Experiments

This framework is useful to understand what we can learn in experiments, survey experiments included.
The lab explores the properties of some commonly used survey experimental designs.

title: Week 3: Panel Surveys
text:
Sign up for final project group using this form 
Panel surveys are surveys where the same respondents are asked questions multiple times. Sometimes these repeat the same questions to understand shifts in public opinion and the effect of events in between waves.
As with last week, the takeaway is that panel surveys are expensive and risk missing subjects across waves, this is called panel attrition. With fixed budgets, one may wonder if we are better off just conducting a one-shot survey, also called a cross-section with an increased sample size.
We have no new lab assignment this week. Instead, we will spend some time revisiting the lab from last week. I plan to spend some time comparing one-shot and panel surveys with simulations.

title: Week 2: Representative Surveys
text:
We start the topic of public opinion with representative surveys. As the name suggests, a representative survey is administered to a sample of respondents that resemble the demographic characteristics of the underlying population.
The punchline of this week is that conducting a true representative survey via random sampling is near impossible. Instead, most surveys use some form of quota or stratified sampling to ensure that the sample obtained resembles the population of interest.
The lab assignment for this week will be a guided introduction to R. By the end, we will compare different sampling techniques.

title: Week 4: Sensitive Questions
text:
When surveys deal with sensitive topics, there is a chance that respondents conceal the truth in their answers. We call this sensitivity bias. This week, we review research designs that seek to reduce sensitivity biases by asking sensitive questions indirectly. Asking indirect questions takes attention away from the sensitive attitude of interest and ensures respondent anonymity.
The takeaway for this week is that these techniques reduce sensitivity bias, but they do so at the expense of statistical precision, so they may not always improve our ability to measure sensitive attitudes and behaviors. We illustrate this point in the lab.

title: Week 4: Sensitive Questions

The takeaway for this week is that these techniques reduce sensitivity bias, but they do so at the expense of statistical precision, so they may not always improve our ability to measure sensitive attitudes and behaviors. We illustrate this point in the lab.

 Oliveros, Virginia and Daniel W. Gingerich. 2020. “Lying About Corruption in Surveys: Evidence from a Joint Response Model.” International Journal of Public Opinion Research 32 (2): 384-395

title: Convenience Samples
text:
Last week we learned about survey experiments. These are increasingly being conducted of convenience samples of online survey respondents. This brings questions about whether the results of experiments can generalize to the population of interest. When a finding can be generalized to a broader population, we say that it has external validity.
The lab explores the concept of external validity and its different flavors.

title: Convenience Samples
text:
Last week we learned about survey experiments. These are increasingly being conducted of convenience samples of online survey respondents. This brings questions about whether the results of experiments can generalize to the population of interest. When a finding can be generalized to a broader population, we say that it has external validity.
The lab explores the concept of external validity and its different flavors.

title: Field Experiments I
text:
The next two weeks are about field experiments, also known as randomized controlled trials (RCTs) or A/B testing. These are experiments aimed testing the impact of a policy intervention.
Field experiments are diverse both in terms of design and their domains of application, hence the need for two weeks.
The lab focuses on the stepped-wedge or staggered adoption design.

title: Beyond Experimentation
text:
We use experiments to understand whether a policy would work. We usually care about whether said policy works outside of the experimental setting. Experiments alone do not answer that question. Which opens a conversation on the scope and limitations of using experiments to inform policy-making.
The lab illustrates these ideas by trying to compare experiments in different contexts.

title: Beyond Experimentation
text:
Lab
Limitations of experiments

title: Quasi-experiments I
text:
Experiments are helpful tools in trying to determine whether a policy works. But in many cases experimentation is unethical or unfeasible. In these contexts, researchers can try to leverage features of naturally occurring data that provide comparable levels of control. These are called quasi-experiments because we are assuming we can analyze them as if they were experiments.
The lab introduces regression discontinuity designs, a common answer strategy for policies that use deterministic thresholds to determine eligibility.

title: Quasi-experiments I

title: Final Project Template
text:
The introduction should take no more than two pages and summarize the project. From, it should be clear:

What are you studying
What we know about it so far
Why it is important to study it further
What are you proposing to do
What research design are you using
How good the research design is
What challenged does your proposal or research design face

title: Final Project Template
text:
Model
Here you encode your beliefs about the world. What are the main outcomes of interest? How are they distributed, what is their range? Are there any endogenous and exogenous variables to consider?
Formulating these beliefs about the world as a directed acyclic graph or as potential outcomes may help clarify what to code.

title: Final Project Template
text:
Inquiry
Here you specify and justify the main quantity of interest. Why these quantity and not others? You can have more than one inquiry if you deem it necessary, but you should explain why you need more than one.

title: Final Project Template
text:
Data strategy
Here you specify how would you collect data from the world. Is this an experiment? How will you assign conditions? Why did you choose this design over other alternatives? Why did you choose to ask the survey question in this way?

title: Final Project Template
text:
Answer strategy
Here you specify the procedures to summarize your data. You should convince the reader here that the estimator you choose is the best approximation available to the inquiry of interest, so you should mention at least one alternative or explain whether a superior estimation procedure is not available in this application.
